repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Technical Assistance Project for
            Privatization, Enterprise, and Banking Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Rated according to both its original and
            refocused objctives, the project's performance was
            unsatisfactory. It is likely that the modest achievements of
            the project will be sustainable. With regard to Bank
            performance, the International Development Association (IDA)
            has not played a substantial role in the privatization
            processin Egypt, though its catalytic role in strengthening
            the institutional capacity of public enterprises, even with
            all its shortcomings, formed an important base for the
            eventual continuation of the process. Overall, Bank
            performance was rated satisfactory. Borrower performance was
            deficient overall. Key lessons learned included the
            following: strong commitment from Borrowers is needed for
            technical assistance. when there are doubts about government
            commitment, proper safeguards should be built into the
            project design. Secondly, risks should be identified and the
            likelihood of their occurrence assessed and taken into
            account in the project design. Third, where Borrower
            commitment to a project has weakened, and willingness to use
            IDA funding has become insufficient, decisions to cancel the
            project should be made early. Fourth, Constraints should be
            taken into acount in establishing realistic targets. Fifth,
            the timing of privatization should be carefully assessed
            while an economic reform or structural adjustment program is
            underway. Sixth, the Bank should consider whether to offer
            technical assistance for a fee.
